body_text.text: Social isolation (the objective state of having few social relationships or infrequent social contact 3 with others) and loneliness (a subjective feeling of being isolated) are serious yet underappreciated 4 public health risks that affect a significant portion of the adult population. Social isolation is a risk 5 factor for development of loneliness but some persons enjoy it (e.g., hermits). Conversely, having 6 social relationship does not assure that loneliness will not develop, because the social relationship 7 has to be meaningful. Many people feel lonely under the best of circumstances. Approximately one-8 quarter (24 percent) of community-dwelling Americans aged 65 and older are considered to be 9 socially isolated, and a significant proportion of adults in the United States report feeling lonely (35 10 percent of adults aged 45 and older and 43 percent of adults aged 60 and older) 1 . 11 Loneliness is even more common in long-term care institutions. The prevalence of severe 12 loneliness among older people living in care homes is at least double that of community-dwelling 13 populations: 22-42% for the resident population compared with 10% for the community 14 population. 2 . One study found that more than half of nursing home residents without cognitive 15 impairment reported feeling lonely 3 . A study in Malaysian nursing homes using UCLA loneliness 16 scale found that all residents felt lonely, 25% moderately and 75% severely 4 . Unfulfilled need for 17 meaningful relationships and losing their self-determination due to institutionalization play crucial

Feeling of loneliness has many deleterious consequences. They include increased risk of depression, 23 alcoholism, suicidal thoughts, aggressive behaviors, anxiety and impulsivity 1 . Some studies found 24 that loneliness is also risk factor for cognitive decline and progression of Alzheimer's disease, 25 recurrent stroke, obesity, elevated blood pressure and mortality 10 . Lonely older people may be 26 burdened by more symptoms before death and may be exposed to more intense EOL care compared 27 with nonlonely people 11 .

Loneliness has three dimensions; the first one is personal loneliness which is often related to the 29 absence of a significant person like a spouse or partner that provides emotional support and is 30 someone who affirms one's value as a person. The significant someone could be a pet, because pet 31 ownership decreases loneliness 12 . The second dimension of loneliness is absence of a sympathy 32 group, which can include 15 to 50 people who are seen regularly. This may be a card group, bridge 33 or canasta or another popular game Bingo, that many retired seniors enjoy. The third dimension is a 34 lack of an active network group, consisting from 150 to 1500 people, who provide support just by In all countries impacted by Covid-19 the message that is being sent by government officials and 38 medical experts is "stay at home" and "isolate in place". The isolation is especially difficult for 39 people living in nursing homes and assisted living communities. Most facilities have asked that no 40 one enters the facilities unless they work there because there is a high risk that COVID-19 would 41 spread rapidly once it is introduced. Group activities have been canceled and, in many facilities, 42 residents are eating in their rooms as all communal dining has been stopped. Although prohibiting 43 group activities will decrease the risk of spreading the Covid-19 infection in nursing homes it 44 significantly increases the isolation and resulting loneness of residents 13 . 45

Long-term care facilities also prohibit visits from outside, including visits by family members. This is 46 especially burdensome for residents with cognitive impairment and dementia. Many family 47 members of these residents visit often, sometimes every day, bring food and help the residents with 48 eating and drinking 14 . If they cannot visit, they may be afraid that the resident will no longer 49 recognize them. 50

The following ideas are easy to implement, with little or no cost or hiring additional staff and can 51 decrease the loneliness of residents in nursing homes or assisted living communities: 52 1. Name tags. Ask residents and staff if they would wear a plain name tag, white with black 53

New Roman lettering. Font should be at least one half inches high. The name tag will 54 have the name the person wants to be called on it. Ours would have Dr. Volicer, or 55 Joyce on our name tags. The staff will also have to wear their "official" facility name 56 tag, but they are very difficult for an elderly person with some vision impairment to 57 read. Wearing a name tag that can easily be read helps to make a connection between 58 the staff and residents. can look out a window and see their families. 75 5. Urge families to send cards and letters. The activity staff will have a social history of each resident and 80 will know their religion. The Activity Department might be encouraged to have items that can be sorted, like 99 buttons or small pieces of fabric. Residents can be asked to help sort items and put 100 them into small bowls. The resident sorting buttons must be a person who would not 101 try to eat one as this would be quite dangerous. Take three packs of cards and mix them 102 up and ask a resident to sort them. Make sure the packs are very distinctive, so it will be 103 easy to decide what pack they belong in and thank them when they completed the task. 104
Nursing home residents often feel hopeless as rarely does anyone thank them for doing 105 something. This is a great opportunity to have a resident feel as if they are needed. 106

Conclusions. Preventing loneliness in institutionalized persons is at least as important as helping 107 them with personal hygiene. This is especially important when during the Covid-19 epidemic 108 residents must be protected from contact with other individuals to reduce the risk of infection.

FIGREF3.text: Some residents with dementia are comforted with realistic toy dogs, cats or life like 83 looking dolls. If a resident develops a fondness for either of them the family might agree 84 to purchase one. It seems that men particularly like dogs. They can be purchased on 85 amazon.com and are less than $20. Stuffed animals or dolls cannot be shared because 86 of infection control issues. There is also some evidence that robotic animals (robopets) 87 may be effective in decreasing loneliness of older adults in residential care setting 16 . 88 8.
